You may also like Team Modeller Enquire now Hook-Up Portable Whiteboards Enquire now Custom Printed Portable Whiteboards Enquire now Logovisual have previously supplied whiteboard panels for our London office, so when we needed whiteboards for a room at our head office we got in touch. The end result looks good â€“ many thanks. ADRIAN SHAH-CUNDY, VOLKER WESSELLS All looks fantastic thank you!! The guys were a pleasure to meet and it was all so hassle free. CHARLOTTE WALTERS, TUNGSTEN NETWORK Commissioned Logovisual to design and install a folding wall in one of our technology rooms. Both our company and the NHS Trust were absolutely delighted with the installation a first for all. PETER SALT, IMMERSIVE Clear and prompt communication throughout and a very smooth installation process. Nothing was too hard. Highly recommended! TRACEY COVE, STEVENS & COVE Excellent, high quality product, purchased after wise advice and installed quickly by friendly installers. Perfect product for our meeting room needs. MIA ELLIOTT, DIOCESE OF GUILDFORD The board looks great! And Iâ€™d like to say your installers were absolutely fantastic, so friendly, organised and cleaned up. JESS MARTIN, VAYNERMEDIA Logovisual really understood our brief and made some great suggestions to make our designs come to life. They helped us bring a childâ€™s game from a small tin to a life size piece of experiential, for us to take in to store at John Lewis. Everyone loved it. Thank you guys. TAMARA SPURWAY, WILD & WOLF As a product, they really provide a varied functionality to aid in our brainstorming and project works. These mobile whiteboards have really been an excellent investment and are immensely popular with our staff. SEBASTIAN FRANCIS-JONES, C SPACE The whole process from start to finish was excellent and the final product was second to none. Highly recommend Logovisual and the team and will be using them again very soon for the next project. LYNNE BRODA, OXFORD CARTOGRAPHERS The install was fab the guys were excellent and we all love the wall, so much in fact we are thinking of future projects including them. Once again canâ€™t thank you enough for a great thorough service. ZOE HARRIS, CBRE GLOBAL INVESTORS Logovisual had as I believed to be the simplest and hassle free job on the project, install of white boards. They were in and out within 3 hours, a job well done! THE PROJECT TEAM, OVERBURY PLC The product itself is superbly built and easy to manoeuvre around with the attached wheels. From the office teamâ€™s communication before our event to the delivery teamâ€™s installation and pickup I found everyone to be really helpful and very professional going out of their way to meet our deadlines. I would certainly recommend logovisual. SHAUN Oâ€™HARA, SAATCHI & SAATCHI WELLNESS We were looking for a new â€œcanvasâ€ to share information and encourage joint thinking. The Thinking Wall turned out to be the perfect solution. Thereâ€™s room to be expansive and for things to have real impact. The service we received right from our first enquiry, to installation (very fast, very painless) has been excellent. STEPHEN CROWE, SCOTTISH FUNDING COUNCIL We were pleased with the high level of customer service, our order was dealt with quickly and efficiently and we are thrilled with the finished product. The custom whiteboards that are exactly as we had envisaged them. STEVE CROSTHWAITE, HOTSPUR PRIMARY SCHOOL Just wanted to thank you again for your help, had a small amount of feedback from our client: Whiteboards are superb. Even better than expected! LEE, IDEA UK DESIGN & MARKETING The products look amazing and your team were clean, tidy and considerate. Adorned with 105mm howitzer shells and featuring a full-sized "Flying Tigers" P-40 Warhawk dramatically crashing through the wall, this bar is a celebration of military valor. Initially built to honor military personnel, it soon became a beloved gathering spot for first responders as well. It attracts these patrons and honorees as well local regulars, nighttime partiers, and Tampa visitors alike. Located in the heart of Ybor City on the vibrant 7th Avenue, the Bad Monkey has become one of Tampa's most famous and spirited bars. 1717 E 7th Ave. Tampa, FL 33605 Contact Us: info@badmonkeyybor.com Mon-Sun 12PM - 3AM Home Happy Hour Events Event Reservation About Location fb twitter instagram Â©2025 Copyright The Bad Monkey All Rights Reserved.

Stop by during normal business hours to speak with a manager or call (813) 280-9971 to book your party now! You can also fill out the form below, and someone will get in touch with you shortly. Capacity The Bad Monkey offers 3 areas for events: Main Bar Back Monkey Patio Bar VIP Lounge (Located Upstairs) We welcome parties large and small! About the Bad Monkey Bar in Historic Ybor City Menu Happy Hour Events Sports Bar Host an Event About Location Contact Fb Twitter Instagram About The Bad Monkey Bar is dedicated to those who serve their country and/or community. You will know you are at the right place when you see 6 full sized 105 mm howitzer shells sitting on the bar with craft beer taps sticking out of them, as well as a full-sized â€œFlying Tigersâ€ P-40 Warhawk crashing through the wall overhead. Taps can be â€œownedâ€ for the night on a pay-as-you-pour basis, and you can go upstairs to the VIP Lounge to play pool or relax in our outdoor â€œBack Monkeyâ€ Patio Bar. 17 televisions make this a great place to watch your favorite sports team and host watch parties. If you are hungry, you can order from our pub grub menu (all options $10). We offer 12 beers on tap including locally brewed favorites and a premium well with the best Happy Hour in Ybor. We are cigar friendly with handmade house cigars made right here in Ybor City. The Bad Monkey Venue Main Bar Our main bar offers a premium well along with 12 favorite and local craft brews flowing from 105mm howitzer shells front and center on the bar. Our selection of top-shelf liquor canâ€™t be matched. Ask the bartender to show you our merchandise, which includes an assortment of regular, â€œblingâ€, and special event t-shirts, caps, and koozies, as well as hand-crafted cigars rolled by Yanko a block down the street. If you are hungry, order from our menu of pub grub â€“ all items $10. For special occasions with groups of 10 or more, you can reserve your own beer tap â€“ we will hook up one of our center bar beer towers and let you manage your own fun. Just pay for what you pour. Socialize, watch whatâ€™s on TV, build a giant Jenga tower, throw darts or play shuffleboard at the Bad Monkey Ybor. Groups of up to 100 may reserve the East bay of the bar for private functions. Back Monkey Patio Bar Visit the Back Monkey patio bar to relax in the great Ybor outdoors. Full bar available with four draft beers for events or special occasions along with plenty of seating at the bar or under one of Ybor Cityâ€™s oldest trees. The area is equipped with big screen TVs, so you can catch the game and a grill if you want to exercise your tailgating skills. Book this unique area for your next party of up to 40, or just come on back next time you visit the bar to get away from the crowd. VIP Lounge (Upstairs) The upper level of the Bad Monkey, known as the VIP lounge , gives guests the feeling of being on the bridge of an aircraft carrier looking down over the flight deck. This open space has private couch seating, a pool table and a big screen TV that can be used to project slides for business meetings. The pool table can also be converted into a conference or buffet table upon request. Book this area for meetings or small private events of 25 to 30 people. Join our Team If you are interesting in becoming part of the Bad Monkey experience, fill out this application . The Bad Monkey Ybor City - 1717 E 7th Ave, Tampa, Florida Menu Happy Hour Events Sports Bar Host an Event About Location Contact Fb Twitter Instagram Location Address: 1717 E 7th Ave. Tampa, FL 33605 Navigating Ybor: Ybor City is laid out in a traditional urban grid pattern with Avenues running East-West and Streets running North-South. Avenue numbers start at Adamo Drive and increase as you move to the north. The entertainment district begins at 13th Street to the west (by Hampton Inn) and increases as you move to the east toward 22 street (end of the retail district). Everybody giving directions in Ybor will use Avenue and Street numbers to guide you. Parking: If you want to park close to the bar, there is a privately owned lot behind the Monkey. Rates range from $3 to $10, depending on the day (rates go up on the weekend and during events). If you donâ€™t mind a two block walk, park in the covered Centro city lot (16th Street just south of 7th Avenue directly south of the Centro Ybor complex). The garage is secure and itâ€™s just $1 for 3 hours, except for Thursday through Saturday when there is a flat fee ($6 on Thurs, $8 on Fri, and $10 on Sat). You should also note that any city-owned surface lot in Ybor offers free parking all day Saturday until 10 pm and all day Sunday until 3 am Monday morning. Several of these city lots are within 3-4 blocks of the bar (the closest is behind Carmineâ€™s restaurant at 18th St and 8th Ave, Lot 5 ). From the Founder: Monkey on My Back - T. Digital Skip to content 972-383-9791   |   contactus@t.digital Linkedin Twitter Vimeo Facebook Instagram Home About TDigital Our Founder Presentations Our Services Training Products FrontGate by TDigital Fortza by TDigital Community Outreach Standups DFW*ATW | 2025 Standup Weekend Center for Children and Families | 2024 Standup Weekend Itâ€™s Going to Be Okay | 2023 Standup Weekend Standup Out of the Box Tech Talks Contact Menu Home About TDigital Our Founder Presentations Our Services Training Products FrontGate by TDigital Fortza by TDigital Community Outreach Standups DFW*ATW | 2025 Standup Weekend Center for Children and Families | 2024 Standup Weekend Itâ€™s Going to Be Okay | 2023 Standup Weekend Standup Out of the Box Tech Talks Contact From the Founder: Monkey on My Back This past week, I had the pleasure of hosting my friend, Admiral Brian Hurley in my graduate Salesforce CRM solutions class at the University of Texas at Dallas. As we sat in our round table discussions, Admiral Hurley brought up a particular article that had not crossed my mind in many years. It happens to be one of the best-selling Harvard Business Review publications of all time. â€œManagement Time: Whoâ€™s Got the Monkeyâ€ ( original article here ). This HBR essay discusses the three types of management time. The first is boss-imposed time â€œused to accomplish those activities that the boss requires and that the manager cannot disregard without direct and swift penalty.â€ The second is system-imposed time â€œused to accommodate requests from peers for active support.â€ Finally, Self-imposed time â€œused to do those things that the manager originates or agrees to do.â€ As managers, we are constantly challenged with the simple fact that there is just not enough time in the day, but our teams seem to be running out of work to do. The idea is that thereâ€™s a metaphorical monkey, the problem , and people tend to trade off this monkey to others with no real solution. The article specifically tracks the relationship between manager and team member (in the original article referred to as the subordinate). â€œSubordinate-imposed time begins the moment a monkey successfully leaps from the back of a subordinate to the back of his or her superior and does not end until the monkey is returned to its proper owner for care and feeding. In accepting the monkey, the manager has voluntarily assumed a position subordinate to his subordinate.â€ The issue is that the team member is handing off a problem back to their boss when they should be solving it themselves. So how do we take on the task of getting the proverbial monkey off our back? Here are my main takeaways from the HBR article for my own daily business operations: Triage problems. Does it take a quick 5 second web search to figure out the answer or is it going to take a few hours to solve? A quick 5 second Google search can be redirected to team members but a problem that takes a few hours to solve might be a worthy learning opportunity for me and my team. Encourage incorrect solutions.Â  I donâ€™t mean to encourage bad programming. Rather, itâ€™s okay to make a mistake. I would much rather have someone present a wrong solution to a problem than no solution at all. It shows drive and initiative. It also aids in the learning process. Students remember a question they got wrong on a test longer than the question they got right. It means the student will internalize how to solve this problem and the ethos that surrounds the topic for the problem at hand. They will be much more in-tune with the program and ready to tackle the next (similar) challenge. Facilitate Q&A. Often people are unsure of what they donâ€™t know. Sometimes people are afraid to ask questions out of fear that they will appear unintelligent; but that feeds the cycle. If they donâ€™t ask questions, they never learn. Itâ€™s vital to the project to encourage our teams to ask questions and to not penalize them when they get something wrong. It is our turn to share the knowledge. Demand excellence. There is a difference between someone who knows how to arrive at the correct solution and tries but fails, and someone who doesnâ€™t try. Demand excellent attempts. Despite the outdated reference to mail , I feel that these rules are still valuable today. In my graduate class, I strongly encourage leadership. Nothing is more powerful than a good leader who pushes team members to take the initiative to solve problems. Managersâ€™ days are consumed with solving rudimentary issues that should not be on their desk. And I hear this from many of my colleagues. We want to foster a learning environment, but struggle with keeping othersâ€™ tasks from becoming our own. social Media Facebook-f Twitter Linkedin Vimeo Thanawalla Digital Salesforce Architecture, Development, Implementation and Management Experts for Large Enterprises Contact Us Email: contactus@t.digital Phone: 972-383-9791 Dallas, Texas Â© 2025 All Rights Reserved. Customer Reviews for The Bad Monkey in Ybor City Menu Happy Hour Events Sports Bar Host an Event About Location Contact Fb Twitter Instagram Customer Reviews Book An Event The Monkey Spotlight The Bad Monkey is a tribute to, and haven for, our heroes, offering a thrilling blend of history and nightlife. Adorned with 105mm howitzer shells and featuring a full-sized "Flying Tigers" P-40 Warhawk dramatically crashing through the wall, this bar is a celebration of military valor. Initially built to honor military personnel, it soon became a beloved gathering spot for first responders as well. It attracts these patrons and honorees as well local regulars, nighttime partiers, and Tampa visitors alike. Located in the heart of Ybor City on the vibrant 7th Avenue, the Bad Monkey has become one of Tampa's most famous and spirited bars. 1717 E 7th Ave. Tampa, FL 33605 Contact Us: info@badmonkeyybor.com Mon-Sun 12PM - 3AM Home Happy Hour Events Event Reservation About Location fb twitter instagram Â©2025 Copyright The Bad Monkey All Rights Reserved.
